Award.AbstractNarration: This effort will organize an NSF CAREER Proposal Writing Workshop to introduce junior faculty to the NSF CAREER program, and help them prepare their CAREER proposal. The NSF CAREER program serves a critical role in the National Science Foundation's efforts to identify, foster and support the nation's most promising junior faculty in both research and education. Junior professors who are just starting their careers often have limited experience with grant writing and evaluation. They also have little or no interaction with the program directors at NSF. During this workshop, young faculty members will have the opportunity to improve their skills in proposal writing, as well as interact with NSF program directors from different divisions (IIS, CNS, and CCF) as well as recent NSF CAREER awardees. The major components of the workshop include presentations on proposal writing, experience sharing, mock panels, and proposal clinic. A limited number of travel support will be made available for HBCU/MEI faculty to attend this workshop. This 1-day event is tentatively scheduled to be held on March 15, 2013 at Temple University Center City campus, located opposite to Philadelphia City Hall in downtown Philadelphia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project is to organize a workshop for junior faculty (untenured faculty who are on the tenure-track) to help them better prepare for the NSF CAREER proposal. The workshop activities include presentation by NSF program officers and past career awardees. Workshop participants also had an opportunity to take part in a mock panel review with sample proposals from all three core programs, IIS, CNS, and CCF. 
 
In terms of broader impacts, we had a total of 100 junior faculty attend the workshop. Efforts were made to encourage faculty  underrepresented groups, as well as faculty teaching in HBSUs and MSIs, to attend the workshop. This was done via offering travel grants to these faculty members to help offset the cost of attending the workshop. Approximately 40% of the participants are from the above mentioned groups. We maintained a website with the relevant information for participants to continue to access after the workshop.

The outcomes of this award is the successful conclusion of the workshop. Out of the 100 participants, at least 21 of of them have been awarded the CAREER award to date. Since many of the workshop participants are in the first 2-3 years of their faculty appointment, we expect that this number will continue to grow beyond the lifetime of this award.
